I started the home loan process with BOV 35 weeks ago, and to this day, I still do not have a confirmed date for the final deed. 
There have been no delays on my end, as this is not my first property—I’m fully familiar with the procedures and paperwork involved.
The notary’s file was submitted in November, and yet, according to the latest email I received last week, the file is somehow still stuck in the pre-vetting stage which makes no sense because I had received an official email from BOV on the 19th of December, stating that the assessment was finalized and everything was in order. The next step, according to the email, was that the legal office would contact my notary with a date.
Emails and phone calls have been of no help. Every time I reach out, I am passed from one person to another, and all I hear is "someone is working on it" or "you have to wait." I understand that processes need to be followed, but these long delays are completely unacceptable.
This ongoing delay is putting me at risk of losing the entire property. On top of that, all the extra costs for extension letters are falling on me as the client. 
If the promise of sale falls through, I will be left with notary costs, bank fees, architect fees, and the life and home insurances which I have been paying from October 2024 when the BOV employee that was taking care of my loan process told me to apply and start them. Not to mention, I’ll have to start searching for another property in a market where prices have already risen.
It’s incredibly disappointing to see 
Bank of Valletta
 advertise about having the best home rates, only to fail in delivering timely service and proper support for their clients. 
This situation has become beyond frustrating now.

Terrible Experience with 
Interni Italia by Attaguile
 – Avoid at All Costs
Detailed Review:
We really regret going with Interni and making the trip all the way to Sicily, hoping to get quality furniture. Save yourself the hassle and money—there are way better companies in Malta you can go with instead.
We trusted the recommendations from family and friends who had used them before, but this was NOT the same company they described. The dining table we ordered barely had any info in the brochure, so we relied heavily on their supposed “expertise.” They kept reassuring us they knew their products inside and out. Well, they didn’t. The colour of the dining table changed twice—once when we made the final payment (which we reluctantly accepted because we didn’t want to lose the deposit), and again upon delivery. The table we got in the end was nothing like what was promised. All this while communicating in fluent Italian as English is very poorly spoken at Interni.
On top of that, the workers they sent were rude, unprofessional, and even damaged our gypsum ceiling during installation without bothering to tell us. 
To make matters worse, they admitted that the designer who worked on our project doesn’t even work with the company anymore (which says a lot). We were also told that they had received negative feedback about one of the installers that they sent to our house—and yet, they still continued contracting him to their clients. 
After weeks of back-and-forth to discuss the issue of the dining table, Interni were dodging us, offering nothing but a fruitless video call. We even reached out to the owner and told him we’d be going public with this nightmare.
Interni's Response: 
The owner challenged us to pursue legal action and accused us of trying to “blackmail” him with a negative review. He claimed to also have advised his lawyer of the same. (We didn’t even bother replying to that ridiculous written message. The next morning, the owner kept trying to contact us, asking for an in-person meeting.)
We finally met with one of their Interior Design Consultants, who basically claimed they had delivered what we ordered, and couldn’t care less that we were misled by two of their designers. During the meeting we explained that the designer could have provided samples of the dining table’s color but didn’t, and that critically, the table we received didn’t match the brochure description. In the end, their only offer was a measly €200 for the inconvenience caused by the installers.
Presently, this case is being investigated by the European Consumer Centre as the Malta consumer affairs Authority has no jurisdiction over Interni since its an Italian registered company. This makes it harder for you to conclude cases. So beware.
Bottom line: 
Stay away from Interni if you care about quality service or professionalism. In hindsight, we trusted that Interni would take care of us far too much, which was a mistake. However, being given a table that is different from the brochure was completely beyond our control and entirely their fault. We have since done business with Styles Furniture in St. Venera and had a very positive experience.

Kelna lift li kien ilu installat ftit aktar min 3 snin u hlief problemi ma jaghtix.
Darba kul hmistax kien jieqaf. Min wahlu kien igib kul skuza, daqqa d-dawl u daqqa l-ovr, etc. Meta qabzitilna iddecidejna li nibdlu l-kumpanija u mmorru ma ohra.
Iccekjajna ma hafna kumpaniji u ghazilna Eleva lifts. Meta l-lift u l-installazjoni gie spezjonat minnhom, harget cara li kelna nibdlu hafna parts minnhu ghax kienu ta' kwalita nferjiru sa anke l-lift kif kien installat u l-qaghada li kien fih, kien perikoluz. Dhalna fi spiza kbira ghax kwazi bdilnih kollu.
Min hawn infahhar l-efficjenza, l-kwalita tax-xoghol u l-profesjonalita ta' @Eleva liftaMalta. Honestament, veru jahdmu bilghaqal u joqghodu attenti ghal kwalita tax-xoghol.
Dan nista nghidu ghax ahna tista tghid li konna mahhom il-hin kollu waqt li jahdmu. L-owner ta Eleva Lifts mar 'out of his way' sabiex jara li nkunu moqdijin kif suppost, b'lift ta' kwalita u minghajr ma jdahhalna fi spejjez zejda. Keep it up Eleva Lifts Malta. 
Grazzi 
Silvio Diandra Desira
/

I'm writing to express my outmost disappointment in part of the staff of the Welbee's store in St. Julian's. The story is from a few minutes ago when I entered the store, as I usually do, right before work. I entered wearing headphones (again - as I always do) and suddenly I do see the entire store staring at me. I turn around and see the security (the morning shift on the 17.02.2025) walking towards me, clapping and calling my name as if I'm some type of a dog.
I take off my headphones and ask if I can help with anything, to which he responds saying that I must leave my bag in the lockers. Mind you I do enter the store with a bag on an almost daily basis and I do not believe I should leave my bag in the lockers (that often give off errors or are broken), keeping in mind that it contains my work laptop and I am responsible for it outside of my work location.
I proceed explaining all that to him, as well as the fact that I do enter the store every day with a bag and he proceeds to insists on me leaving it. After a brief argument and me letting him know I shall not leave my bag, I am told that I can keep it but I will have to show its contents upon leaving the store. Although I do believe that this insinuates the fact that I am stealing, which is neither within my culture nor my education, or is complicit to the way I was raised, I agree as I know that I have not, nor am I going to, do anything wrong.
I proceed with looking for what I went in for, when another employee (usually standing up right next to the cash registers behind a desk) walks towards me and also insists on me leaving my bag. I explain to him that I do come into the store every day with a bag and somehow this is the first time that I've been stopped. I also let him know that there are cameras in the store and they can check the fact that I am always wearing a bag in the morning. I do also point out a few ladies that are wearing bags, to which he responds telling me that mine is a backpack, while theirs is a laptop briefcase.
I then proceed to leave the store as I see no point in continuing to argue with them as they kept on repeating and not even listening to what I'm trying to say.
I do find the attitude towards customers absolutely atrocious starting from the clapping and yelling, to implications of me stealing, to the absolute invasion of privacy and personal space.

BOV
 Sliema Preluna , today you really and truly failed to provide a satisfactory service.... and this is not a first either, but today topped them all!!
The majority of times that we need to use Sliema Preluna branch, other than the fact of excessive wait time and not enough chairs.... we end up either having 'half' a solution or being 'half' served! 
Today we walked in with just 1 client in line, (we had to wait a few minutes to get in to the branch as the security officer had gone to get a glass of water from upstairs). Once it was our turn, we explained to the young lady at reception (she always has a nice smile, but I cant recall her name) what our issue was, since she could not or did not know how to resolve the issue, she asked Nicole for assistance. 
Ms Nicole didn't know how to solve the issue either, so she asked us to wait while she went upstairs to ask someone else for a solution..... we waited a good 10 minutes, while Nicole went upstairs. We then saw Nicole come back down the stairs, she nodded as in acknowledgement and went on her way to another desk further in! 
So we waited for Ms 'Receptionist' who had also left her desk to look for some box belonging to another client. When she came back from her errand, I asked if she had any news as we had been waiting for more than we thought was necessary. 
Believe it or not she went to ask Nicole who gave her the reply (which she most probably knew did not solve our issue). So why on earth didn't you Nicole tell us what the reply was??. Why did you just walk by and nod, especially considering that you most probably knew that the issue was not going to be solved? When I asked you why you walked by you said that you had relayed the message to Ms Receptionist, but one of you was lying as Ms Receptionist said that she would ask you, we actually saw her doing so!
This incident compelled me to write here as not only once again did we end up with no solution, but to add insult to injury it felt like we weren't treated appropriately at all!!!
I think clients that end up having to go to a branch should have their issue resolved, not have to wait more than necessary, should be treated decently, and the team at this particular brnch should stop failing to provide a satisfactory and humane service.
You may ask why did I not write to their customer resolution office... Weil the last time I did, it didn't get me anywhere either, apart from the fact that I got an email to fill in their survey!

Hi everyone, 
I want to share with you guys my frustrating experience with Traslo_GO Malta, a shipping company locally based. Just before Christmas, I shipped 5 suitcases from Milan to Malta, but one of them never arrived. Instead, I received a completely different parcel (belonging to someone else) with my luggage’s shipping label stuck on it. This clearly proves that the label detached and was mistakenly affixed to another package — a courier error, not mine.
While Traslo_GO Malta did communicate with me and claimed to have asked their agents about the missing luggage, they have not provided any actual proof like emails or similar (which I asked for) of their recovery efforts — only assurances through Facebook Messenger. 
Despite this, they refused to take full responsibility, and shifted the blame to their subcontractor (Poste Italiane) and on me for "not having attached the label properly". However, the incorrect delivery shows that the issue was caused by mishandling during transit, not by me.
On top of this, I was never shown or asked to sign any Terms and Conditions before shipping. I paid via Revolut, yet never received an invoice or receipt for the transaction, which raises concerns about transparency.
Their only offer was a minimal refund (€45), which does not reflect the financial or sentimental value of our lost belongings. I expected a higher level of accountability and customer support, but instead, I have been left with no real resolution.
I’m sharing my experience so others can make an informed decision before trusting this company with their shipments. Transparency and responsibility are key in this industry, and unfortunately, I did not experience either to a satisfactory level.

Not served by GO plc!

I recently checked my balance on my GO prepaid mobile and was surprised to find only €0.02 left, despite being certain I had a large amount topped up. Since I have another mobile number with a contract with epic, I rarely use the GO number, so I contacted GO’s customer care on Whatsapp to verify any deductions.
To my surprise, I was told that I must physically visit a GO outlet just to check my own usage history. This is not only inconvenient but completely unreasonable—especially for those who are elderly, infirm, or unable to visit a store easily.
Customers should have the right to access their usage details remotely!

All we seem to be getting from GO these days are price increases for features we do not want or need. How about they start by implementing basic improvements in the core services we actually do use instead?

GO, please wake up, improve your service and respect your customers' time!
#GOMalta #CustomerService #DoBetter #consumerprotection

Today, we encountered an unacceptable experience with our recent Wolt order. The restaurant confirmed that we were supposed to receive six pieces, yet the box arrived completely unsealed, with everything turned upside down and only two pieces inside. Although we submitted a complaint to Wolt, and it was eventually resolved, this situation highlights a significant flaw.
I strongly urge all restaurants that offer delivery to adopt a policy of sealing their boxes securely or at the very least, enclosing them in a tamper-proof plastic bag. This is just a suggestion; it is essential for ensuring accountability. If a courier were to mishandle our food, it should be immediately obvious due to a torn seal. Implementing this standard is crucial for maintaining trust and safeguarding the customer experience.

If you value good customer service, reliability, and value for money, I would 𝐍𝐎𝐓 recommend 𝐞𝐣𝐜𝐒 𝐋𝐭𝐝 as a condominium association.
Things started off well, and we were hopeful, but unfortunately, around 2023 things took a very frustrating turn.
Getting in touch with them has been such a challenge—emails often go unanswered, phone calls aren’t picked up, or they disconnect and then you get a text saying, “I’ll call you later” or “tomorrow,” but that call never comes. Messages on WhatsApp are read but rarely replied to, which only adds to the frustration.
We wanted a good explanation of the yearly fee which kept increasing so we asked for a meeting... another headache. They scheduled specific dates and times, only to be cancelled before or we’re given a date but no time, and when we email to check, there’s no response, and the meeting just doesn’t happen.
It’s been exhausting trying to get things done, and honestly yesterday they told us to look for another association which is a blessing... still I wonder what's going to happen with the money I paid for the lift as it hasn't been fixed since July 2024 and when I asked them I was told: 
"𝐊𝐮𝐥𝐥 𝐭𝐰𝐞𝐠𝐢𝐛𝐚 𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠𝐡𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐛'𝐦𝐨𝐝 𝐮𝐟𝐟𝐢𝐜𝐜𝐣𝐚𝐥𝐢 𝐦𝐞𝐭𝐚 𝐢𝐥-𝐛𝐥𝐨𝐤𝐤𝐚 𝐭𝐚𝐡𝐭𝐚𝐫 𝐚𝐦𝐦𝐢𝐧𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐮𝐫 𝐢𝐞𝐡𝐨𝐫. 𝐇𝐚𝐧𝐝𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫 𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠𝐡𝐚𝐭𝐚 𝐥𝐢𝐥𝐮"
Life is short and for the sake of your sanity, look elsehwere.

Not served by the 
Building & Construction Authority
 (BCA). The developer of the site next to us is excavating right next to our wall, not observing any of the 76cm distance required by law. The BCA washed their hands by saying they won't get involved because this is a civil matter that we will need to handle through the courts, despite that the method statement (and the Civil Code) requires the developer to observe this 76cm distance.
The developer has already hit our corridor wall through carelessness during demolition, displacing a brick (which he verbally promised to repair later). If something similar happens at the basement levels, it could cause the whole building to collapse. We had informed the developer through a representation that we do not waiver our right to this 76cm distance. 
Our lawyer told us we need to file an injunction with the court to stop the excavation, but warned that the developer would likely retaliate by countersuing us for stopping works, exposing us to financial risk. Even if we win the subsequent court case, we would only be awarded damages of around €10-20,000 which would need to be shared or prorated between all neighbours in the apartment complex. Our portion would likely be less than €2,000, which wouldn't even cover the income we'd lose from work and other expenses to pursue this case.
Developers know they are operating with impunity, because the legislative, enforcement, and judicial systems are rigged in their favour, and there is nothing we neighbours can do to protect our rights and our safety.
-------------
Update: I would like to thank everyone who provided helpful advice. I'm going to address some common points and misconceptions (paraphrased):
"The 76cm distance doesn't apply because the developer is removing loose material, not rock cutting." - That is not correct. Apart from the soil and rubble, the developer is also removing their foundations that are situated right next to our wall. The Avoidance of Damage to Third Party Property Regulations defines excavation as "the cutting or removal of rock, clay and any other natural or human placed material, that forms part of the land, or the removal of any consolidated material". The foundations and rubble both qualify as "human placed material". Both the BCA and our lawyer have confirmed that the 76cm distance still applies in this case. We might have refrained from objecting if the developer was really just removing loose material and keeping the foundations in place, but they are clearly removing the foundations too.
"The developer is removing material thrown there by your own developer." - That is not the case. There was a building on this site (now demolished) that existed long before our apartment block was built.
"The 76cm distance doesn't apply because your block has a basement wall there, not bedrock." - That is also not correct. The 76cm distance applies from the surface level, not from the base of the third-party wall. Both the BCA and our lawyer have confirmed this.
"Your developer didn't respect the 76cm distance either." - The former building on this site was uninhabited when our block was built, so there was no safety risk. But that's beside the point. We did not gain anything from it if our developer also excavated illegally. We paid the full price for our apartment on the assumption that it was constructed legally. And even if it wasn't, one illegality doesn't justify another.
"Damage will be covered by the developer's insurance." - Insurance does not cover damage if the developer is found to have been breaking the law, which is the case here.
"It is safer to proceed this way than to build over the old foundations." - That may or may not be the case. We would have been ready to talk with the developer, with the guidance of our architect, if he had approached us about it. However, the developer deceitfully stated they would respect the 76cm distance in the method statement, so we never got the chance to evaluate whether not doing so is safe or not.
"You are making mountains out of molehills." - The developer has already hit our corridor wall with heavy machinery through carelessness. You can imagine what will happen if there is similar carelessness applied when excavating right next to our block's basement wall.
"You don't know what you're talking about." - My position has been corroborated by my lawyer and the BCA, who have seen the same photos that I've posted above (and others). I appreciate that some commenters are expressing their disagreement with the definition of "excavation" in good faith, but I can see that others are coming from developers or their associates, who have a vested interest in sowing confusion and discrediting posts like this one. Anyone can verify the law for themselves: https://legislation.mt/eli/sl/623.6/eng.
"Call 138." - We did. That number goes to the BCA, who told us they won't intervene because it's a civil matter.
"Talk to a lawyer." - We did. He was ready to file an injunction on our behalf, but we concluded we would be worse off, for several reasons. We are currently living in a rented apartment since we don't feel safe staying next to this construction site. Stopping the excavation through an injunction would mean we'd have to continue paying rent for much longer during the court case and the subsequent resumption of works. Residential leases have a one-year minimum period, so we can't just stop renting and go back to our apartment for a few months while excavation is stopped, even if it was safe to do so. The court is unlikely to award us compensation for this rent. The case will require lots of our time, which the court doesn't award compensation for either, so we would end up suffering a huge financial loss even if we win the case. The developer will likely retaliate by countersuing us for stopping works as a form of SLAPP, which would put even more financial strain on us. In brief, pursuing such a court case would require a lot of disposable financial resources that we don't have.

I would like to commend Elia Caterers for exceeding my expectations yesterday! I wanted to order some cakes through Wolt. I called them to check if they had other cakes available apart from the ones listed since I wanted a choc one which would not be very messy apart from another almond cake. The girl answering the phone call explained that they can send a simpler chocolate one - I just need to leave a note on the Wolt order. She took my name to make sure that they send the right cake when the order comes in. The cake available on Wolt was a bit more costly which I did not mind paying for since ordering through Wolt saved me the trip to Hamrun. When the cakes were delivered, I was quite surprised that they sent a separate envelope with cash for the difference in price. Thank you Elia - cakes were lovely - all the guests enjoyed them especially the Almond Cherry Frangipan! Will surely order again, always served well by Elia! Exceptional customer service!

Like visiting St. Julians? Feeling peckish or downright hungry? A fan of Turkish food? Then look no further than 
Alem Turkish
. A newly-opened, family-run business which serves, hand on heart, the best turkish food I ever tried. Everything is made fresh daily (including the bread!) by the owners themselves! The mixed grill (for 2) was enormous yet disappeared very quickly thanks to yours truly. The pide (boat-shaped pizza) was also gargantuan and delicious according to my 9-year old little big champ. We also sampled baklava which was utterly delicious, devoid of excessive honey and not too sweet; with the right balance of filo and pistachios. I must also stress that prices are very competitive and far from typical of such an elite area. Highly recommended!
